dialogs.original: Tell not me. When the butt is out, we will drink water.Not a drop before. Therefore bear up and board 'em.Servant- monster, drink to me.
dialogs.translated: Dont tell me that. When the wine barrel is empty, well drink water. But we won't drink even a drop of water before then. Therefore, raise the bottle and drink. [To CALIBAN] Servant-monster, drink a toast to me.

dialogs.original: Servant-monster? The folly of this island. They say theres but five upon this isle. We are three of them. If th' other two be brained like us, the state totters.
dialogs.translated: Servant-monster? What foolishness is found on this island! They say there are just five people on the island. Were three of them. If the other two are as crazy as us, our country is going to collapse.

dialogs.original: Drink, servant-monster, when I bid thee. Thy eyes are almost set in thy head.
dialogs.translated: Drink when I tell you to, servant-monster. Your eyes look sunk into your head.

dialogs.original: Where should they be set else? He were a brave monster indeed, if they were set in his tail.
dialogs.translated: Where else should his eyes be sunk? Hed be quite a remarkable monster if his eyes were sunk in his tail.

dialogs.original: My man-monster hath drowned his tongue in sack. For my part, the sea cannot drown me.   I swam, ere I could recover the shore, five and thirty leagues off and on. By this light, thou shalt be my lieutenant, monster, or my standard.
dialogs.translated: My servingman-monster is so drowned in the wine hes drunk that he cant even talk. For my part, not even the sea can drown me. Before I reached the shore from the shipwreck, I swam a hundred and five miles. Therefore, monster, youll be my lieutenant, or my flag-bearer.

dialogs.original: Your lieutenant, if you list. Hes no standard.
dialogs.translated: Make him your lieutenant, please. He can barely stand up straight, much less hold a flag.

dialogs.original: Well not run, Monsieur Monster.
dialogs.translated: Well never run in our army, Sir Monster.

dialogs.original: Nor go neither. But youll lie like dogs, and yet say nothing neither.
dialogs.translated: Or even walk. Instead youll lie there like sleeping dogs and say nothing.

dialogs.original: Mooncalf, speak once in thy life, if thou beest a good mooncalf.
dialogs.translated: Monster, if you want to be a good monster, please say something.

dialogs.original: How does thy honor? Let me lick thy shoe.   [indicates TRINCULO]  Ill not serve him. Hes not valiant.
dialogs.translated: How are you, my lord? Let me lick your shoe. [He points to TRINCULO] I wont serve him. Hes not brave the way you are.

dialogs.original: [to CALIBAN]    Thou liest, most ignorant monster. I am incase to justle a constable. Why, thou deboshed fish, thou, was there ever man a coward that hath drunk so much sack as I today?   Wilt thou tell a monstrous lie, being but half a fish and half a monster?
dialogs.translated: [To CALIBAN] Youre lying, you most ignorant monster. Im so brave I would go brawl with a police officer right now. Why, you drunk fish, you: has any coward ever drunk as much wine as I have today? Are you telling such monstrous lies just because youre half-fish, half-monster?

dialogs.original: [to STEPHANO]  Lo, how he mocks me! Wilt thou let him, my lord?
dialogs.translated: [To STEPHANO] Look, hes making fun of me! Will you let him do that, my lord?

dialogs.original: Lord, quoth he? That a monster should be such a natural!
dialogs.translated: Lord, he says? That monster is such an idiot!

dialogs.original: [to STEPHANO]  Lo, lo, again! Bite him to death, I prithee.
dialogs.translated: [To STEPHANO] Look, look, hes mocking me again! Please, bite him to death.

dialogs.original: Trinculo, keep a good tongue in your head. If you provea mutineer, the next tree. The poor monsters my subject and he shall not suffer indignity.
dialogs.translated: Trinculo, if you dont have anything nice to say, dont say anything at all. And if you dont listen to me, Ill hang you from the next tree. This poor monster is my loyal subject, and I refuse to let him be insulted.

dialogs.original: I thank my noble lord. Wilt thou be pleased to hearken once again to the suit I made to thee?
dialogs.translated: Thank you, my noble lord. Now would you be willing to listen once again to the request I made to you before?

dialogs.original: Marry, will I. Kneel and repeat it. I will stand, and so shallTrinculo.
dialogs.translated: Indeed, I will. Kneel and repeat your request. Ill stand and listen, and so will Trinculo.

dialogs.original: [kneeling]  As I told thee before, I am subject to a tyrant, a sorcerer that by his cunning hath cheated me of the island.
dialogs.translated: [Kneeling] As I told you before, Im enslaved to a tyrant, a magician who used his magic to steal the island from me.

dialogs.original: Thou liest.
dialogs.translated: [Mimicking TRINCULO's voice]  You lie.

dialogs.original: [to TRINCULO]  Thou liest, thou jesting monkey, thou! I would my valiant master would destroy thee. I do not lie.
dialogs.translated: [To TRINCULO] No you are lying, you joking monkey, you! I wish my brave master would kill you. I did not lie.

dialogs.original: Trinculo, if you trouble him any more in s tale, by this hand, I will supplant some of your teeth.
dialogs.translated: Trinculo, if you interrupt his story again, I swear by my hand, Ill knock out some of your teeth.

dialogs.original: Why, I said nothing.
dialogs.translated: But I didnt say anything.

dialogs.original: Mum, then, and no more. Proceed.
dialogs.translated: Quiet, then, no more. Continue.

dialogs.original: I say, by sorcery he got this isle.    From me he got it.   If thy greatness will    Revenge it on himfor I know thou darest,    But this thing dare not
dialogs.translated: I was saying: he used magic to take over this island. He took it from me. If your Highness will take revenge on himbecause I know that you're brave enough to do it, though this thing [He points to TRINCULO] wouldn't dare

dialogs.original: Thats most certain.
dialogs.translated: Thats obvious.

dialogs.original: Thou shalt be lord of it and Ill serve thee.
dialogs.translated: Youll be lord of the island, and Ill serve you.

dialogs.original: How now shall this be compassed?Canst thou bring me to th' party?
dialogs.translated: How can all this be accomplished? Can you bring me to him?

dialogs.original: Yea, yea, my lord. Ill yield him thee asleep,Where thou mayst knock a nail into his head.
dialogs.translated: Yes, yes, my lord. Ill take you to him when he's asleep, then you can smash a nail into his head.

dialogs.original: Thou liest. Thou canst not.
dialogs.translated: [Mimicking TRINCULO's voice] You lie. You cant do that.

dialogs.original: What a pied ninnys this! Thou scurvy patch!    I do beseech thy greatness, give him blows    And take his bottle from him.   When thats gone,    He shall drink naught but brine, for Ill not show him    Where the quick freshes are.
dialogs.translated: What a motley fool he is! You are a wretched fool! Please, your Highness, punch him a few times and take his wine bottle away from him. When he doesn't have that, hell drink nothing but salt waterbecause I won't show him where the freshwater springs are.

dialogs.original: Trinculo, run into no further danger. Interrupt the monster one word further, and, by this hand, Ill turn my mercy out o' doors and make a stockfish of thee.
dialogs.translated: Trinculo, stop trying to cause trouble. If you interrupt this monster one more time then, I swear by my hand, I'll stop being nice and beat you until you're as stiff as a piece of dried fish.

dialogs.original: Why, what did I? I did nothing. Ill go farther off.
dialogs.translated: Why, what did I do? I didnt do anything. I need to move away from you.

dialogs.original: Didst thou not say he lied?
dialogs.translated: Didnt you just say that he lied?

dialogs.original: Thou liest.
dialogs.translated: [Mimicking TRINCULO's voice] You lie.

dialogs.original: [to TRINCULO]  Do I so? Take thou that.  [beatsTRINCULO]  As you like this, give me the lie another time.
dialogs.translated: [To TRINCULO] Oh, do I? Take that, then. [He hits TRINCULO] There's more where that came from if you say that I'm a liar again.

dialogs.original: I did not give the lie. Out o' your wits and hearing too? A pox o' your bottle! This can sack and drinking do. A murrain on your monster, and the devil take your fingers!
dialogs.translated: I didnt say you were a liar. Are you out of your mind, and deaf, too? A curse on your wine bottle! This is what drinking wine does to you. May your monster get the plague, and you can go to hell!

dialogs.original: Ha, ha, ha!
dialogs.translated: Ha, ha, ha!

dialogs.original: Now, forward with your tale.Prithee, stand farther off.
dialogs.translated: Now, continue with your story. Trinculo, please, stand farther away.

dialogs.original: Beat him enough. After a little time,Ill beat him too.
dialogs.translated: Beat him up some more. After a little while, Ill beat him up too.

dialogs.original: Stand farther.Come, proceed.
dialogs.translated: Stand even farther away, Trinculo.[To CALIBAN] All right, continue.

dialogs.original: Why, as I told thee, tis a custom with him,    I' th' afternoon to sleep. There thou mayst brain him,    Having first seized his books;   or with a log    Batter his skull; or paunch him with a stake;    Or cut his weasand with thy knife.   Remember    First to possess his books, for without them    Hes but a sot, as I am, nor hath not    One spirit to command. They all do hate him    As rootedly as I. Burn but his books.    He has brave utensilsfor so he calls them    Which when he has a house, hell deck withal.    And that most deeply to consider is    The beauty of his daughter.   He himself    Calls her a nonpareil. I never saw a woman,    But only Sycorax my dam and she.    But she as far surpasseth Sycorax    As greatst does least.
dialogs.translated: Well, as I told you, its his habit to take a nap in the afternoon. Thats when you can smash in his skull, after youve first stolen his books. Or you could hit him on the head with a log. Or stab him in the belly with a spear. Or cut his throat with a knife. But remember to steal his books first, because without them, hes just a fool like me, and wont be able to command even one spirit. The other spirits all hate him as completely as I do. Burn everything but his magic books. He has some magnificent furniture and furnishingsat least thats how he describes themthat he plans to use to furnish his house once he gets one. The thing you should focus on though is the beauty of his daughter. Prospero himself says she has no equal. I never saw a woman other than my mother, Sycorax. Miranda is so much more beautiful than Sycorax that its like comparing the most beautiful thing to the least.

dialogs.original: Is it so brave a lass?
dialogs.translated: Is she really such a splendid girl?

dialogs.original: Ay, lord. She will become thy bed, I warrant.And bring thee forth brave brood.
dialogs.translated: Yes, my lord. Shell be a perfect fit for your bed, and shell bear you some excellent children.

dialogs.original: Monster, I will kill this man. His daughter and I will be king and queensave our graces!and Trinculo and thyself shall be viceroys. Dost thou like the plot, Trinculo?
dialogs.translated: Monster, I will kill this man. His daughter and I will be king and queenGod protect our royal selves!and you and Trinculo will be our governors. Do you like that plan, Trinculo?

dialogs.original: Excellent.
dialogs.translated: Excellent.

dialogs.original: Give me thy hand. I am sorry I beat thee. But while thou livest, keep a good tongue in thy head.
dialogs.translated: Give me your hand. Im sorry I beat you up. But for as long as you live, be more polite when you speak.

dialogs.original: Within this half hour will he be asleep. Wilt thou destroy him then?
dialogs.translated: In the next half an hour hell be asleep. Will you kill him then?

dialogs.original: Ay, on mine honor.
dialogs.translated: Yes, I swear on my honor.

dialogs.original: [aside]  This will I tell my master.
dialogs.translated: [To himself] Ill tell my master about this.

dialogs.original: Thou makest me merry. I am full of pleasure.    Let us be jocund.   Will you troll the catch    You taught me but whilere?
dialogs.translated: You make me glad. Im full of happiness. Lets have some fun. Will you sing the song you taught me a short while ago?

dialogs.original: At thy request, monster, I will do reason, any reason.    Come on, Trinculo, let us sing.     [sings]    Flout 'em and scout 'em,    And scout 'em and flout 'em.    Thought is free.
dialogs.translated: Monster, whatever you ask for I'll do, so long as it's reasonable. Come on, Trinculo, lets sing. [Singing]Mock 'em and shock 'emAnd shock 'em and mock 'em.Thought is free.

dialogs.original: Thats not the tune.
dialogs.translated: Thats not the song.

dialogs.original: What is this same?
dialogs.translated: What is this song?

dialogs.original: This is the tune of our catch, played by the picture ofNobody.
dialogs.translated: Thats the song you were singing, played by nobody.

dialogs.original: If thou beest a man, show thyself in thy likeness. If thou beest a devil, take t as thou list.
dialogs.translated: If youre a man who's playing that music, show yourself. If youre a devil, then you can go to hell.

dialogs.original: O, forgive me my sins!
dialogs.translated: Oh, forgive me for all my sins!

dialogs.original: He that dies pays all debts.I defy thee!Mercy upon us!
dialogs.translated: The man who dies pays the ultimate debt. I defy you, devil! God bless us.

dialogs.original: Art thou afeard?
dialogs.translated: Are you scared?

dialogs.original: No, monster, not I.
dialogs.translated: No, monster, not me.

dialogs.original: Be not afeard. The isle is full of noises,    Sounds, and sweet airs that give delight and hurt not.    Sometimes a thousand twangling instruments    Will hum about mine ears, and sometime voices    That, if I then had waked after long sleep,    Will make me sleep again.   And then, in dreaming,    The clouds methought would open and show riches    Ready to drop upon me, that when I waked    I cried to dream again.
dialogs.translated: Dont be frightened. The island is full of noises, sounds, and sweet music that will delight you and not hurt you. Sometimes I hear a thousand instruments playing in my ears, and sometimes I hear voices that send me back to sleep even if I had just woken up. And once asleep again, I dream of clouds that open up to show that they carry riches, which will soon drop down on me like rain. So when I woke up, I begged to dream again.

dialogs.original: This will prove a brave kingdom to me, where I shall have my music for nothing.
dialogs.translated: This will be a splendid kingdom for me to rule. I'll get music played to me for free.

dialogs.original: When Prospero is destroyed.
dialogs.translated: Once you kill Prospero.

dialogs.original: That shall be by and by. I remember the story.
dialogs.translated: That will be done soon. I remember our plan.

dialogs.original: The sound is going away. Lets follow it, and after do our work.
dialogs.translated: The sound is going away. Lets follow it, and complete our plan after that.

dialogs.original: Lead, monster; well follow. I would I could see this taborer. He lays it on.
dialogs.translated: Lead on, monster. Well follow. I wish I could see this drummer. He's very good.

dialogs.original: Wilt come? Ill follow, Stephano.
dialogs.translated: Coming, monster? Im right behind you, Stephano.
